description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily-- Research findings on Life Science Research- Reproduction and Fertility are discussed in a new report. Financial supporters for this research include Department of Biotechnology, Government of West Bengal, Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of India.
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life
Science Daily \-- Research findings on Life Science Research \- Reproduction
and Fertility are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting
originating from Haryana, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,
"An early and precise diagnosis of pregnancy in cows is critical to short the
calving interval and to improve their reproductive efficiency. Neutrophils are
the first blood cells to sensitize the embryo in the uterus and participate in
maternal recognition of pregnancy after getting induced by interferon tau
(IFNt)."

Financial supporters for this research include Department of Biotechnology,
Government of West Bengal, Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of
India.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Indian Council of
Agricultural Research (ICAR) National Dairy Research Institute, "To study the
protein abundance ratio, blood samples were collected on 0th, 10th, 18th and
36th day post-artificial insemination (AI) from crossbred Karan Fries cows.
Neutrophils were isolated through density gradient centrifugation and studied
for protein abundance by high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with
mass spectrometry (LC-MS). Protein abundance ratios for Myxovirus resistance
(MX1 and MX2) were found to be higher (p <0.05) on day 10 and day 18 post-AI,
whereas Oligoadenylate synthetase-1 (OAS1) and Interferon stimulated gene-15
ubiquitin-like modifier (ISG15) proteins were more abundant on day 18 post-AI.
The relative mRNA expressions of these molecules were also studied by qPCR.
The gene expression of ISG15, MX1, MX2 and OAS1 was found to be higher (p
<0.05) on day 10th, 18th and 36th post-AI compared to day 0."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The study indicates
that ISGs on blood neutrophils are essential for the establishment of
pregnancy and may be targeted as potential biomarkers for pregnancy diagnosis
in cows."

For more information on this research see: Proteomics and transcriptomics
study reveals the utility of ISGs as novel molecules for early pregnancy
diagnosis in dairy cows. _Journal of Reproductive Immunology_ ,
2020;140():103148. _Journal of Reproductive Immunology_ can be contacted at:
Elsevier Sci Ireland LTD, Customer Relations Manager, Bay 15, Shannon
Industrial Estate CO, Clare, Ireland. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Journal of Reproductive
Immunology \- <http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-reproductive-
immunology/>)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting S.K. Mohapatra, Dept. of Animal Biochemistry, Indian Council of
Agricultural Research (ICAR) National Dairy Research Institute, Karnal,
Haryana 132001, India. Additional authors for this research include B.SK.
Panda, D. Chaudhary, M.N. Alhussien, R. Kapila and A.K Dang.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jri.2020.103148>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the _Journal of Reproductive Immunology_ is:
Elsevier Sci Ireland LTD, Customer Relations Manager, Bay 15, Shannon
Industrial Estate CO, Clare, Ireland.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Studies from Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) National Dairy Research Institute in the Area of Reproduction and Fertility Described (Proteomics and transcriptomics study reveals the utility of ISGs as novel molecules for early ...): Life Science Research - Reproduction and Fertility
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Research findings on Life Science Research - Reproduction and Fertility are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Haryana, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “An early and precise diagnosis of pregnancy in cows is critical to short the calving interval and to improve their reproductive efficiency. Neutrophils are the first blood cells to sensitize the embryo in the uterus and participate in maternal recognition of pregnancy after getting induced by interferon tau (IFNt).”

Financial supporters for this research include Department of Biotechnology, Government of West Bengal, Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of India.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) National Dairy Research Institute, “To study the protein abundance ratio, blood samples were collected on 0th, 10th, 18th and 36th day post-artificial insemination (AI) from crossbred Karan Fries cows. Neutrophils were isolated through density gradient centrifugation and studied for protein abundance by high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (LC-MS). Protein abundance ratios for Myxovirus resistance (MX1 and MX2) were found to be higher (p <0.05) on day 10 and day 18 post-AI, whereas Oligoadenylate synthetase-1 (OAS1) and Interferon stimulated gene-15 ubiquitin-like modifier (ISG15) proteins were more abundant on day 18 post-AI. The relative mRNA expressions of these molecules were also studied by qPCR. The gene expression of ISG15, MX1, MX2 and OAS1 was found to be higher (p <0.05) on day 10th, 18th and 36th post-AI compared to day 0.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “The study indicates that ISGs on blood neutrophils are essential for the establishment of pregnancy and may be targeted as potential biomarkers for pregnancy diagnosis in cows.”

For more information on this research see: Proteomics and transcriptomics study reveals the utility of ISGs as novel molecules for early pregnancy diagnosis in dairy cows. Journal of Reproductive Immunology, 2020;140():103148. Journal of Reproductive Immunology can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ireland LTD, Customer Relations Manager, Bay 15, Shannon Industrial Estate CO, Clare, Ireland. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Journal of Reproductive Immunology - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-reproductive-immunology/)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting S.K. Mohapatra, Dept. of Animal Biochemistry, Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) National Dairy Research Institute, Karnal, Haryana 132001, India. Additional authors for this research include B.SK. Panda, D. Chaudhary, M.N. Alhussien, R. Kapila and A.K Dang.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jri.2020.103148. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the Journal of Reproductive Immunology is: Elsevier Sci Ireland LTD, Customer Relations Manager, Bay 15, Shannon Industrial Estate CO, Clare, Ireland.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
